title: About Me
text:
EDUCATION
University of Delaware (Delaware, U.S.)
Master of Public Policy 2025
- Thesis: “Why do governments adopt (or abandon) gender-responsive budgeting? The case of Australia.” (Advisor: Jonathan B. Justice)
Chung-Ang University (Seoul, South Korea)
Master of Public Administration 2018
- Thesis: “Influencing elements of trust in government.” (Advisor: Sunghan Cho)
- Graduate Assistant Scholarship, 2016 – 2017 
Bachelor of Public Policy 2016

title: About Me
text:
RESEARCH & TEACHING EXPERIENCE
Research Assistant Jan 2023 – Dec 2024
University of Delaware (Delaware, U.S.)
- Conducted research on gender-responsive budgeting under the advisement of Dr. Justice.
- Performed comprehensive literature reviews, sourced relevant data, and carried out both qualitative and quantitative analyses. - Facilitated interviews, synthesized findings, and prepared materials for academic conferences (ABFM 2023 & 2024).
- Currently developing thesis and journal article manuscripts based on ongoing research outcomes.
Teaching Assistant August 2023 – Dec 2023
University of Delaware (Delaware, U.S.)
- Assisted Dr. Elizabeth Fournier with [HLPR/UAPP 211] Introduction to Public Health,
- Graded and evaluated student assignments, providing detailed feedback and comments, supported in-class group activities, offering guidance and clarifying course content, held office hours to address student questions, review course materials, and provide additional support.
Graduate Assistant August 2022 – Jan 2023
University of Delaware (Delaware, U.S.)
- Contributed to the development and implementation of the Biden School’s annual survey, sourced information, conducted background research, and crafted survey questions and formats.
Research Assistant Jan – Oct 2021
Korea Institute of Public Administration (Seoul, South Korea)
- Sourcing information, data analysis, editing articles, supporting interviews, seminars and meetings.
Research Assistant Apr – Jul 2019
Korea Institute of Public Administration (Seoul, South Korea)
- Sourcing information, data collection and analysis, supporting seminars and meetings.
Researcher Feb 2019
Architecture & Urban Research Institute (Sejong, South Korea)
- Investigation of research ethics in annual publications.
Researcher Dec 2018
Korean Women’s Development Institute (Seoul, South Korea)
- Investigation of research ethics in annual publications.
Researcher Nov 2018
Korea Institute of Public Administration (Seoul, South Korea)
- Investigation of research ethics in annual publications.
Research Assistant Jul – Aug 2017
Korea Institute of Public Administration (Seoul, South Korea)
- Making educational content and PowerPoint presentations for Rwanda’s public officers.
Research Assistant Jul – Dec 2017
Korea Forest Service (Daejeon, South Korea)
- Evaluated agency’s annual performance.
Research Assistant Aug 2017
Korea Research Institute for Local Administration (Wonju-si, Gangwon-do, South Korea)
- Designed and visualized framework of public organizations.
Research Assistant Jul – Oct 2017
Korea Radio Promotion Association (Seoul, South Korea)
- Researched to resolve fringe areas in South Korea.
Research Assistant May – Aug 2017
National Research Council of Economics, Humanities and Social Sciences (Sejong, South Korea)
- Investigation of research ethics in annual publications.

title: About Me
text:
PRESENTATION
“Why do governments adopt (or abandon) gender-responsive budgeting? The case of Australia,”
Association for Budgeting and Financial Management (ABFM), Cleveland, OH, 2024

2024 Public Finance and Budgeting Northeastern Workshop, Newark, NJ, 2024
“Gender-Responsive Budgeting Themes and Variation,”
Association for Budgeting and Financial Management (ABFM), Denver, CO, 2023
“Government trust in South Korea, 2013 – 2016,”
Sino-US International Conference for Public Administration, Beijing, China, 2018.

title: About Me
text:
COMPETENCIES & INTERESTS
Language Skills: Korean (Native), English (IELTS Band 7; CEFR C1)
IT Skills: R, SPSS, Microsoft Office Suite, AMOS

title: Assignment 2
text:
Google Trends data
1. Use Google Trends website (https://trends.google.com/home)
2. Use gtrendsR package to collect data (use gtrendsR01.R program)

title: Assignment 2
text:
Codes

Trouble shooting
I set the code: {r, error=TRUE}
This pushes Quarto: “Even if there’s an error in this chunk, keep rendering the document.”




Trump & Harris Election data
My gtrendsR() chunk is currently being blocked by Google Trends and may not display data.

library(gtrendsR)
TrumpHarrisElection = gtrends(c("Trump","Harris","election"), onlyInterest = TRUE, geo = "US", 
                              gprop = "web", time = "today+5-y", category = 0) # last five years

Error in get_widget(comparison_item, category, gprop, hl, cookie_url, : widget$status_code == 200 is not TRUE

the_df=TrumpHarrisElection$interest_over_time

Error: object 'TrumpHarrisElection' not found

plot(TrumpHarrisElection)

Error: object 'TrumpHarrisElection' not found

tg = gtrends("tariff", time = "all")

Error in get_widget(comparison_item, category, gprop, hl, cookie_url, : widget$status_code == 200 is not TRUE

title: Assignment 04
text:
Scraping Foreign reserve data from Wikipedia





library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(rvest)


Attaching package: 'rvest'

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    guess_encoding

url <- 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign-exchange_reserves'

#Reading the HTML code from the Wiki website
wikiforreserve <- read_html(url)
class(wikiforreserve)

[1] "xml_document" "xml_node"    

# Grab ALL tables on the page
tables <- wikiforreserve %>%
  html_nodes("table") %>%
  html_table(fill = TRUE)

length(tables)

[1] 4








# Gender Inequality Index (GII) data

# Input the url
gii_url <- "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_Inequality_Index"
gii <- read_html(gii_url)

# Check tables
gii_tables <- gii %>%
  html_nodes("table") %>%
  html_table(fill = TRUE)

length(gii_tables)

[1] 5

# Modification
gii_total <- gii_tables[[2]]
head(gii_total)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  `GII Rank` `HDI Rank` Country     `GII Value`
       <int>      <int> <chr>             <dbl>
1          1          2 Switzerland       0.025
2          2          1 Norway            0.038
3          3         11 Finland           0.039
4          4          8 Netherlands       0.043
5          4         10 Denmark           0.043
6          6          7 Sweden            0.045

gii_top <- gii_tables[[3]]
head(gii_top)

# A tibble: 6 × 9
  Country     `GII Rank\n(GII value) 2018` `GII Rank 2012` `GII Value 2012`
  <chr>       <chr>                                  <int>            <dbl>
1 Netherlands 4 (0.041)                                  1            0.045
2 Sweden      2 (0.040)                                  2            0.055
3 Denmark     2 (0.040)                                  3            0.057
4 Switzerland 1 (0.037)                                  4            0.057
5 Norway      5 (0.044)                                  5            0.065
6 Finland     7 (0.050)                                  6            0.075
# ℹ 5 more variables: `HDI Rank 2012` <chr>, `GII Rank 2011` <chr>,
#   `GII Value 2011` <chr>, `GII Rank 2008` <chr>, `GII Value 2008` <chr>

gii_btm <- gii_tables[[5]]
head(gii_btm)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  Country                GII Rank\n(GII value…¹ `GII Value 2012` `HDI Rank 2012`
  <chr>                  <chr>                             <dbl>           <int>
1 Yemen                  162 (0.834)                       0.823             160
2 Afghanistan            143 (0.575)                       0.712             175
3 Niger                  154 (0.647)                       0.707             186
4 Congo                  156 (0.655)                       0.681             186
5 Liberia                155 (0.651)                       0.658             174
6 Central African Repub… 159 (0.682)                       0.654             180
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`GII Rank\n(GII value) 2018`
# ℹ 4 more variables: `GII Rank 2011` <chr>, `GII Value 2011` <chr>,
#   `GII Rank 2008` <chr>, `GII Value 2008` <chr>







1. Original Full List

# Checking the table
colnames(gii_total)

[1] "GII Rank"  "HDI Rank"  "Country"   "GII Value"

# Clean up the GII Table
gii_total_clean <- gii_total %>%
  filter(!is.na(`GII Rank`)) %>%
  mutate(
    gii_rank = as.integer(`GII Rank`),
    hdi_rank = as.integer(`HDI Rank`),
    country  = as.character(Country),
    gii_value = as.numeric(`GII Value`)  ) %>%
  select(gii_rank, hdi_rank, country, gii_value)

gii_total_clean <- gii_total_clean %>%
  mutate(data_year = 2019)

head(gii_total_clean)

# A tibble: 6 × 5
  gii_rank hdi_rank country     gii_value data_year
     <int>    <int> <chr>           <dbl>     <dbl>
1        1        2 Switzerland     0.025      2019
2        2        1 Norway          0.038      2019
3        3       11 Finland         0.039      2019
4        4        8 Netherlands     0.043      2019
5        4       10 Denmark         0.043      2019
6        6        7 Sweden          0.045      2019


Note: The Gender Inequality Index (GII) values used in this analysis are from the 2019 dataset, as reported on Wikipedia.


2. GII Top-10 Countries

library(stringr)

# Clean up the GII Top-10 Countries Table
colnames(gii_top)                        # Check the variables

[1] "Country"                    "GII Rank\n(GII value) 2018"
[3] "GII Rank 2012"              "GII Value 2012"            
[5] "HDI Rank 2012"              "GII Rank 2011"             
[7] "GII Value 2011"             "GII Rank 2008"             
[9] "GII Value 2008"            

names(gii_top)[2] <- "gii_2018_raw"      # Renaming
names(gii_top)[4] <- "gii_2012"
names(gii_top)[9] <- "gii_2008"

gii_top_clean <- gii_top %>%
  select(country = Country, gii_2018_raw, gii_2012, gii_2008) %>%
  mutate(
    gii_2018 = str_extract(gii_2018_raw, "\\((.*?)\\)"),
    gii_2018 = str_remove_all(gii_2018, "[()]"),
    gii_2018 = as.numeric(gii_2018),
    gii_2012 = as.numeric(gii_2012),
    gii_2008 = as.numeric(gii_2008)  ) %>%

  select(country, gii_2018, gii_2012, gii_2008) 

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
ℹ In argument: `gii_2008 = as.numeric(gii_2008)`.
Caused by warning:
! NAs introduced by coercion

head(gii_top_clean)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  country     gii_2018 gii_2012 gii_2008
  <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1 Netherlands    0.041    0.045    0.174
2 Sweden         0.04     0.055    0.212
3 Denmark        0.04     0.057    0.209
4 Switzerland    0.037    0.057    0.228
5 Norway         0.044    0.065    0.234
6 Finland        0.05     0.075    0.248


Note: The Gender Inequality Index (GII) values used in this analysis are from the 2018 dataset, as reported on Wikipedia.
3. GII Bottom-10 Countries**

# Clean up the GII Bottom-10 Countries Table
colnames(gii_btm)                        # Check the variables

[1] "Country"                    "GII Rank\n(GII value) 2018"
[3] "GII Value 2012"             "HDI Rank 2012"             
[5] "GII Rank 2011"              "GII Value 2011"            
[7] "GII Rank 2008"              "GII Value 2008"            

names(gii_btm)[2] <- "gii_2018_raw"      # Renaming
names(gii_btm)[3] <- "gii_2012_value"
names(gii_btm)[4] <- "hdi_rank_2012"
names(gii_btm)[8] <- "gii_2008"

gii_btm_clean <- gii_btm %>%
  select(country = Country, gii_2018_raw, gii_2012 = gii_2012_value, gii_2008) %>%
  mutate(
    gii_2018 = str_extract(gii_2018_raw, "\\((.*?)\\)"),
    gii_2018 = str_remove_all(gii_2018, "[()]"),
    gii_2018 = as.numeric(gii_2018),
    gii_2012 = as.numeric(gii_2012),
    gii_2008 = as.numeric(gii_2008)  ) %>%
    
  select(country, gii_2018, gii_2012, gii_2008)

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
ℹ In argument: `gii_2008 = as.numeric(gii_2008)`.
Caused by warning:
! NAs introduced by coercion

head(gii_btm_clean)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  country                  gii_2018 gii_2012 gii_2008
  <chr>                       <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
1 Yemen                       0.834    0.823   NA    
2 Afghanistan                 0.575    0.712    0.797
3 Niger                       0.647    0.707    0.807
4 Congo                       0.655    0.681    0.814
5 Liberia                     0.651    0.658    0.766
6 Central African Republic    0.682    0.654    0.768


Note: The Gender Inequality Index (GII) values used in this analysis are from the 2018 dataset, as reported on Wikipedia.





1. Source Identification
- Wikipedia: Gender Inequality Index (GII)
- Additional datasets: GDP, education (World Bank, UNDP, Gapminder, UNWOMEN, etc.)
2. Web Scraping Tools
- R packages: rvest for scraping, tidyverse for cleaning
- html_nodes() and html_table() to extract HTML tables
3. Cleaning Strategy
- Remove headers/footers
- Convert ranks and values to numeric
- Filter missing values
4. Analysis Plan
- Compare gender inequality by region
- Visualize GII vs GDP/education
- Highlight top/bottom ranked countries
5. Ethical Considerations
- Use public data only
- Document scraping code and source URLs

title: Assignment 04
text:
Scraping Foreign reserve data from Wikipedia
